title: 111_hr4056
content: The "Jobs Opportunity and Business Stability Act of 2009" allows for a credit for small businesses that increase employment under section 45R of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Jobs Opportunity and Business Stability Act of 2009" provides an increased small business employment credit for eligible small business employers. The credit is 15% of the excess of aggregate wages paid in 2010 over 102% of wages paid in 2009, and 10% of the excess of wages paid in 2011 over 102% of wages paid in 2010. Minimum preceding year wages must be at least 50% of the amount described in paragraph (1)(A). The credit under the "Jobs Opportunity and Business Stability Act of 2009" for eligible small business employers is determined based on the increase in aggregate wages paid. The total wages must increase by at least 50% of the amount described in paragraph (1)(A). Eligible small business employers are those who employed an average of less than 20 employees in any taxable year. The credit for eligible small business employers is based on wage increase. Employers must have less than 20 employees and meet the gross receipts test. Wages are defined as per section 3121(a) except for railway labor. The credit for eligible small business employers is based on wage increase and certain rules apply for its application. Taxpayers may elect to have the credit not apply for any taxable year. The tax code is amended to deny double benefits and include the increased small business employment credit as part of the general business credit. The tax code is amended to include the increased small business employment credit as part of the general business credit, with special rules for its application. The tax code is amended to include the increased small business employment credit as part of the general business credit, with special rules for its application, including adjustments to the tentative minimum tax and limitations on the credit allowed. The tax code is amended to include the increased small business employment credit as part of the general business credit, with special rules for its application. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. The tax code is amended to include a credit for small businesses that increase employment, effective for taxable years after December 31, 2009. The Secretary of the Treasury will conduct a public information campaign to inform employers about the credit and study ways to provide similar benefits to nonprofit organizations.
